Posts.Title: lumpectomy due next week meggotty meggotty

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2012 07:10PM evergreen9 wrote: I had a mammogram that aws inconclusive, and then an ultrasound to try to gather more info. Apparently there is a scale the radiologist uses to indicate the level of suspicion there is.My memory is getting sketchy, but I think it was a 4 or 5 point scale, with the highest number being almost certainly cancer. Mine was the second highest number, and it was. Having said that, radiologists don't always agree. e.g., I had an abnormality on an MRI on the top bone of my spine. When a group of radiologists looked at it, one was sure it was cancer, 3 disagreed, one strongly. So try not to second guess. It is hard waiting, I know. But exbrnxgrl is right, it is less likely to be cancer than not. And remember, breast cancer caught early is highly treatable. Even folks like me, where it was caught after it got to the nodes, have good treatment options.
Posts.Title: are 'suspicious' ultrasounds ever NOT cancer? scar3d2death Kareywith3littlekittens

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2012 07:18PM evergreen9 wrote: So much wisdom on this page, I even copied a few comments to read when I get down. Thank you!
Posts.Title: Does the looming dread of recurrence ever go away? lanagraves fondak

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2013 12:45PM evergreen9 wrote: Ditto, on the "why did this happen" routine! I have gotten past that phase now - two years, touch wood - and do have a regime that I developed from reading the research and various books (Anti-Cancer, Foods That Fight Cancer, Dr Susan Lolve's book, etc. I am hoping this regime may aid in delaying or avoiding recurrence... my stats are not very good! 1. Exercise, enough to make you sweat, 30 minutes daily, most days 2. Daily - multigrain /whole grain sources of carbs 3. Fruits and vegetables - lots, ESP cabbage family, berries, shitake and oyster mushrooms, cooked tomatoes, etc. 4. Red meat RARELY and very small portion 5. Primarily fish, eggs, tofu, poultry- lean cuts 6. Green tea - Sencha variety, 3 times a day 7. Supplements - omega 3, Vit D 8. Every night, a drink of almond milk which includes pureed garlic and turmeric as well as tomato sauce. Sounds gross, but it rounds off the foods I try to include daily....
Posts.Title: What changes have you made after dx? Speedy4 msphil

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2012 12:14AM - edited Oct 14, 2012 12:15AM by evergreen9 Now that I am done my treatments, I have a list of foods I try to incorporate every day, including berries, bright vegetables, cabbage family, etc. Then each evening I take my "extra dose" of "Hope this helps, and it can't hurt" food meds: I take about 1 tbsp of turmeric daily, mixed with 1/4 cup organic tomato sauce, 1/8 tsp pepper (supposed to help the body absorb the turmeric) and 1 tsp pureed garlic, all mixed into a paste. All of these are believed to have properties that fight cancer trying to start up again. My oncologist and several books I've read encourage "food as medicine", saying that not enough is known re the components of a food, and whether all of these components survive the manufacture process of a supplement. So I do this instead of supplements, though I do take Vit d. Regardless of what you believe re the food vs supplements issue, there is a lot of evidence at the lab level, of the effectiveness of turmeric in fighting cancer. I don't know of any human studies, which of course will be the "last word" on the topic. But for now, I am taking my turmeric! Check the following website for tons of scientific studies, on turmeric, green tea, etc.' services.oxfordjournals.org/vo... __________________
Posts.Title: My Cancer Diet stagefree ShetlandPony

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 10:06PM evergreen9 wrote: I also have had regular mammograms (age 65) annually and had a clean bill of health with the mammogram of Feb 2010.  Then in Nov 2010, I found the lump (turned out to be 3.5cm).  A mammogram taken then was not indicative of anything; it was the ultrasound that showed strong suspicions, and then the biopsy confirmed it.  My advice to folks with dense breasts?  Get an ultrasound each year, even if you have to pay for it!! As one author said, "Looking for a tumour in a dense breast is like looking for a polar bear in a snowstorm!.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 11:51PM evergreen9 wrote: I finished 6 weeks of rads about 13 months ago, on my right breast, after a lumpectomy and chemo. Rads were uneventful, no problems. No signs of lymphedema. In last several weeks however, I noticed soreness or tenderness when I touch that breast, or roll onto it in bed. No pain from physical activity. No pain at rest. I don't remember hurting myself. What could this be?
Posts.Title: Pain all over radiation site healthy133 evergreen9

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 10:21PM evergreen9 wrote: I agree with what Beesie said about waiting for the surgeon more experienced with breast surgery. Having lots of experience with what he/she will see once you are "cut open", which may present with challenges not seen on the tests to date, leaving clean margins, etc. are all very important skills. I think the research is clear on many types of surgery, that you are better with someone who does a lot of the specific ype you are having done.
Posts.Title: need one answer! Cadillac Cadillac

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2012 10:37PM evergreen9 wrote: My empathy goes out to you, in having to fight with insurance companies. Hopefully your government will get more involved in health care as the years go by. While the Canadian system is not perfect, and there are sometimes waits for elective surgeries, (e.g., hip transplant) with my cancer, everything happened in a timely fashion, and the doctor makes the decisions with my input, according to government guidelines that are consistent for all. The one place we seem to lag is getting approval for new drugs... it seems we lag behind the FDA. Otherwise, from what I read here, treatment methods seem very similar. Good luck to all of you, I learn so much from you!
